title: 'I was homeless as a child in Turkey - now I fear Brexit will stop others from being a success'
text:

As a child, Ferit Özdemir was homeless.
Sleeping rough on the streets of Turkey, he eventually moved to Britain where he sold jewellery on a market stall.
Seven years later, he’s about to open his second cafe, creating new jobs in the process.
But as Brexit looms, the businessman fears the dreams of those coming to Britain for a better life - like he did seven years ago - could vanish.
“Brexit is making everyone worried,” admitted the 30-year-old businessman. Fleur and Ferit Ozdemir (Image: Newcastle Journal)
His Grainger Market cafe, ‘Fez Food’ became an instant hit with foodies after opening three years ago.
On that success, he’s lodged plans to open a second on the ‘biker’ stretch of Westgate Road.
But life wasn’t always this easy for Ferit, who had to overcome huge hurdles to live on Tyneside.
“Turkey isn’t in the European Union. Even though I was married to a UK citizen I had to apply for a visa and pass an English test,” he recalled.
“The visa was about £1,000.
“My wife had to earn over £18,200 and prove that she could support me if I didn’t get a job because I would never be allowed any benefits. Fleur and Ferit Ozdemir, in there Turkish Grand Bazaar in the Grainger Market in 2014 (Image: Newcastle Journal)
“We had to renew the visa two years later, which was again another £1,000 and another test.
“Eventually I could apply for citizenship. So another £1,000 and this time the life in the UK test.
“This process is being made stricter and harder, so yes I do worry as it separates families.”
For Ferit, that’s a fear he knows too well.
“As I child in Turkey I was homeless and lived on the street with my younger brother for a time, so being together as a family is very important to me,” he adds. Read More
